description: The world's first museum dedicated to World War II, opened in October 1944 while the war was still ongoing. Now housed in an ultra-modern building since 2014, it tells the story of Belarus's tremendous suffering and heroism during the war through 8,000 exhibits across 15,600 square meters, including immersive dioramas, authentic military equipment, and cutting-edge technology.
highlights: World's first WWII museum, opened during the war in 1944
Ten themed halls covering the entire war chronology
Immersive dioramas recreating pivotal battle moments
Real tanks, airplanes, and artillery including famous Katyusha rocket launcher
Disturbing concentration camp section - 2.3 million Belarusians killed
tips: Book English-language audioguide or tour in advance for context
Plan at least 2-3 hours for thorough visit
Tickets 4.5-9 BYN, discounts on third Tuesday
On-site cafe and gift shop available
Emotionally heavy - be prepared for disturbing content
vibe: Solemn, powerful, emotionally moving - a profound tribute to Belarus's wartime sacrifice and resilience that demands reflection and respect
